Using labelled data

Source: vignettes/labelled_data.Rmd
labelled_data.Rmd
library(studentenstatistikNRW)
library(labelled)
library(gtsummary)

Resources on Using the Labelled Package

  • Joseph Larmarange - Labelled Package
  • Daniel D. Sjoberg - gtsummary Package
  • Shannon Pileggi - Leveraging labelled data in R
  • Shannon Pileggi - Polished summary tables in R with gtsummary
  • Shannon Pileggi - The case for variable labels in R

Example data frame

Select a random table in studententstatistikNRW::tables:

# https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9057006/getting-strings-recognized-as-variable-names-in-r
df <- get(
  get_table_name(
    tables |> 
      dplyr::slice_sample(n = 1) |> 
      dplyr::pull(tablename)
  )
) 

df
#> # A tibble: 92,402 × 7
#>    GES             BILPG            BILFS2     BINWSB1    DLAND    SEMEST BIL002
#>    <chr+lbl>       <chr+lbl>        <chr+lbl>  <chr+lbl>  <chr+lb> <chr>   <dbl>
#>  1 GESM [männlich] BILPG-05 [Unive… FAC… [1. … FG0… [Gei… 05 [Nor… WS 19…     18
#>  2 GESM [männlich] BILPG-05 [Unive… FAC… [1. … FG0… [Gei… 05 [Nor… WS 19…      3
#>  3 GESM [männlich] BILPG-05 [Unive… FAC… [1. … FG0… [Gei… 05 [Nor… WS 19…     17
#>  4 GESM [männlich] BILPG-05 [Unive… FAC… [1. … FG0… [Gei… 05 [Nor… WS 19…     33
#>  5 GESM [männlich] BILPG-05 [Unive… FAC… [1. … FG0… [Gei… 05 [Nor… WS 19…     23

Variable labels

Show variable labels with labelled::var_label for all variables:


labelled::var_label(
  x = df
)
#> $GES
#> [1] "Geschlecht"
#> 
#> $BILPG
#> [1] "Prüfungsgruppe"
#> 
#> $BILFS2
#> [1] "Fachsemester"
#> 
#> $BINWSB1
#> [1] "Studienbereich"
#> 
#> $DLAND
#> [1] "Land"
#> 
#> $SEMEST
#> [1] "Semester"
#> 
#> $BIL002
#> [1] "Studierende"

Look for

labelled::look_for is meant to help users finding variables in large datasets:

# All variables
labelled::look_for(
  df
)
#>  pos variable label          col_type missing values                           
#>  1   GES      Geschlecht     chr+lbl  0       [GESM] männlich                  
#>                                               [GESW] weiblich                  
#>  2   BILPG    Prüfungsgruppe chr+lbl  0       [BILPG-05] Universitärer Abschlu~

  df,
  "BIL"
)

For more details:


# Tibble as opposed to default printing
labelled::look_for(
  df,
  details = "full"
) |> 
  tibble::as_tibble()
#> # A tibble: 7 × 14
#>     pos variable label          col_type missing levels value_labels class type 
#>   <int> <chr>    <chr>          <chr>      <int> <name> <named list> <nam> <chr>
#> 1     1 GES      Geschlecht     chr+lbl        0 <NULL> <chr [2]>    <chr> char…
#> 2     2 BILPG    Prüfungsgruppe chr+lbl        0 <NULL> <chr [6]>    <chr> char…
#> 3     3 BILFS2   Fachsemester   chr+lbl        0 <NULL> <chr [8]>    <chr> char…
#> 4     4 BINWSB1  Studienbereich chr+lbl        0 <NULL> <chr [68]>   <chr> char…
#> 5     5 DLAND    Land           chr+lbl        0 <NULL> <chr [1]>    <chr> char…
#> 6     6 SEMEST   Semester       chr            0 <NULL> <NULL>       <chr> char…
#> 7     7 BIL002   Studierende    dbl            0 <NULL> <NULL>       <chr> doub…
#> # ℹ 5 more variables: na_values <named list>, na_range <named list>,
#> #   n_na <int>, unique_values <int>, range <named list>

# List columns as character
labelled::look_for(
  df,
  details = "full"
) |> 
  labelled::convert_list_columns_to_character()
#> # A tibble: 7 × 14
#>     pos variable label          col_type missing levels value_labels class type 
#>   <int> <chr>    <chr>          <chr>      <int> <chr>  <chr>        <chr> <chr>
#> 1     1 GES      Geschlecht     chr+lbl        0 ""     "[GESM] män… have… char…
#> 2     2 BILPG    Prüfungsgruppe chr+lbl        0 ""     "[BILPG-05]… have… char…
#> 3     3 BILFS2   Fachsemester   chr+lbl        0 ""     "[FACHS0102… have… char…
#> 4     4 BINWSB1  Studienbereich chr+lbl        0 ""     "[FG01-SB01… have… char…
#> 5     5 DLAND    Land           chr+lbl        0 ""     "[05] Nordr… have… char…
#> 6     6 SEMEST   Semester       chr            0 ""     ""           char… char…
#> 7     7 BIL002   Studierende    dbl            0 ""     ""           nume… doub…
#> # ℹ 5 more variables: na_values <chr>, na_range <chr>, n_na <int>,
#> #   unique_values <int>, range <chr>

Factors

Use labelled::to_factor for easy factor conversion:

df_factor <- df |>  
  labelled::to_factor(
    levels = "labels",
    ordered = TRUE,
    sort_levels = "labels",
    strict = FALSE, # Convert to factor only if all values have a defined label?
    labelled_only = TRUE # for a data.frame, convert only labelled variables to factors?
  )

df_factor
#> # A tibble: 92,402 × 7
#>    GES      BILPG                   BILFS2           BINWSB1 DLAND SEMEST BIL002
#>    <ord>    <ord>                   <ord>            <ord>   <ord> <chr>   <dbl>
#>  1 männlich Universitärer Abschluss 1. und 2. Fachs… Geiste… Nord… WS 19…     18
#>  2 männlich Universitärer Abschluss 1. und 2. Fachs… Geiste… Nord… WS 19…      3
#>  3 männlich Universitärer Abschluss 1. und 2. Fachs… Geiste… Nord… WS 19…     17
#>  4 männlich Universitärer Abschluss 1. und 2. Fachs… Geiste… Nord… WS 19…     33
